Learn

Note: if possible, observe the child for at least 6 hours after rehydration, to be

sure the mother can maintain hydration giving the child ORS by mouth.

Exception: Another severe classification(suspected meningitis, etc.) -

*Too much IV fluids is dangerous in very sick children. Treatment should be

supervised very closely in hospital

*Setup a drip for severe dehydration, but give normal saline only 10 ml per kg

of body weight each hour.

*Then give sips of ORS while awaiting urgent referral.

start
↓

Can you give IV fluids immediately?

Yes
No
↓

Is IV treatment available nearby(within 30 minutes)?

Yes
No
↓

*Refer URGENTLY to hospital for IV

treatment.

*If the child can drink, provide the mother

with ORS solution and show her how to

give frequent sips during the trip or give

ORS by nasogastric tube.

↓

*Start IV fluid immediately.

*If the child can drink, give ORS by

mouth while the drip is set up.

*Weigh or estimate the weight of the child

*Give normal saline IV

*Within the first half hour:

*Rapidly give 20ml of IV per kg body

weight before referral.

*Repeat this amount up to twice if the

radial pulse is weak or not detectable

Plan for the next 5 hours:

*More slowly, give 20ml of IV per kg of

body weight every hour during referral.

*Ensure the IV continues running, but

does not run too fast.


*Refer URGENTLY for further management.

*Release the child every 1-2 hours while awaiting transfer - if

hydration status is not improving, give the IV drip more rapidly.

*Give ORS as soon as the child can drink(5 ml per kg body weight

each hour).

*Reassess the child after 3 hours if he/she is still at the clinic -

Classify hydration and then choose the appropriate plan(A/B/C) to

continue treatment. Refer to hopital no matter the re-classification.

If mother refuse referral or you cannot refer, observe child in clinic

for at least 6 hours after he/she has been fully rehydrated.

↓

Are you trained to use a

nasogastric tube(NG) for

rehydration.

Yes
No
↓

*Start rehydration with ORS solution by tube. Give 20 ml per kg body weight each hour for up to 6 hours.

*Refer URGENTLY for further management.

*Reassess the child every 1-2 hours while awaiting transfer-

If there is repeated vomiting, give the fluid more slowly.

If there is abdominal distension, stop fluids and refer URGENTLY,

After 6 hours, reassess the child if he/she is stall at the clinic. Classify dehydration, then choose and follow

appropriate plan(A/B/C) to continue treatmenet.

↓

Can the child drink?

Yes
No
↓

*Start rehydration with ORS solution by tube. Give 20 ml per kg body weight each hour for up to 6 hours

*Refer URGENTLY for further management.

*Reassess the child every 1-2 hours while awaiting transfer -

If there is repeated vomiting, give the fluid more slowly,

If there is abdominal distension, stop fluid and refer URGENTLY,

After 6 hours, reassess the child if he/she is still at the clinic. Classify dehydration, then choose and follow

appropriate plan(A/B/C) to continue treatment

↓

*Refer URGENTLY to a

hospital for IV or NG

treatment.
